Articles and blog posts I saved to readÂ later:

The Architecture Behind A One-Person TechÂ Startup

An article by Anthony Najjar Simon about how he runs his one-man SaaS usingÂ Django.

  • Low stress, one-person company, run from aÂ flat.
  • Self-funded, taking things slow - he likes taking things slow.
  • Grateful to be standing on the shoulders of the open source giants who went ahead and made the OSS stack we all enjoy and benefitÂ from.
  • Your own context matters when choosing a tech stack. There is no â€œholy grailâ€. I guess this means that you should use what youâ€™re familiar with and what is boring forÂ you.
  • Uses K8s on AWS. He says â€œdont fall into the trap of thinking you need to use it tooâ€ - expertise with these tools was learnt over several years fighting fires on the dayÂ job.
  • Productive because he used the tools he is most familiar with and he can focus onÂ shipping.
  • Django, Celery, PostgreSQL, Python, AWS, Redis. - same as MoneyBar andÂ PipPip.

Boring tech behind a one personÂ SaaS

  • The tech-stack keepsÂ evolving
  • â€œBoringâ€ means â€œwhat Iâ€™m familiar with so that I can focus on theÂ businessâ€
  • Most of his time is spent talking to people and thinking. He spends 15% of his time on engineering. Probably it was more when he was setting stuffÂ up.
  • The methods described in the post are definitely not the best way. Itâ€™s just one way of doing engineering in a very specific type of business. Itâ€™s not the onlyÂ way.
  • Django, Celery, PostgreSQL, Python, AWS, Redis. - same as MoneyBar andÂ PipPip.
  • Uses Ansible for provisioning machines. - YAML files. Should look intoÂ this.
  • â€œGood enough forÂ nowâ€
  • Doesnâ€™t use CI tools, he uses Ansible with a shell script heÂ wrote.
  • Uses Datadog for monitoring and alerting, andÂ PagerDuty.
  • Uses Rollbar, which seems similar toÂ Sentry.
  • Uses Slack, not to talk with humans, but integrations with Rollbar and Datadog, and also slack incoming webhooks to be notified when someone signs up or does something interesting like deletes aÂ thing.
  • Make a â€œdingâ€ sound whenever someone signsÂ up.
  • Heâ€™s always very careful about operational stuff to prevent downtime and outages. Servers are over-provisioned to protect against spikes caused by sudden mediaÂ interest.
  • Avoids working from home or cafe cos its more productive in an office. Productivity is important - make every minute count. He doesnâ€™t often work more than 8Â hours/day.
  • He optimizes for spending less time and making money instead of more time and savingÂ money.
  • Uses Vagrant and virtualbox on an MBP so that dev work is on the same systems as prodÂ infra.
  • Uses 1 monolithic repo. Likes thisÂ approach.
  • He uses contractors!!
  • Usually, the biggest obstacle to building and shipping things is overthinking. What if this, what if that. You are not important at all and no one cares. No one sees. Even if you screw up the initial product launch, no one will care because theyâ€™re not looking. Only when youâ€™ve proved that you deserve their attention will you have any attention andÂ visibility.
  • Think big, start small, act fast.
  • Use boring technology, or whatever tech you want. Just make sure youâ€™re solving an actualÂ problem.
  • Ignore the cargo cult people and ignore the noise. Keep calm and carryÂ on.

Djangos place in a web developmentÂ world

  • Not everything needs to be an SPA
  • Django is a back-end framework, itâ€™ll work with an front-end framework, because separation ofÂ concerns.
  • To use django with an SPA, you could use DRF, or just normal views that return JSON.
  • Reading this makes me want to check out React to see what all the fuss isÂ about.

Cache invalidation

VimÂ abbreviations

  • Cool and all, but not as powerful as snippets IÂ think.
  • Auto correcting typos: teh ->Â the
  • Expanding phrases: kr -> kindÂ regards
  • Multi-line textÂ expansion.
  • It really seems similar to what Iâ€™m using UltiSnipsÂ for.
  • I found this question on SO comparing abbreviations and snippets. TLDR: Itâ€™s easier to add and maintain snippets than abbreviations, and you have less boilerplate with snippets than abbreviations, especially in complexÂ cases.

To fix the social sciences, look to the â€œdark agesâ€ of medicine

Emotional resilience in leadershipÂ report

3 virtues of aÂ programmer

  • Laziness - The quality that makes you go to great effort to reduce overall energy expenditure. It makes you write labor-saving programs that other people will find useful and document what you wrote so you donâ€™t have to answer so many questions aboutÂ it.
  • Impatience - The anger you feel when the computer is being lazy. This makes you write programs that donâ€™t just react to your needs, but actually anticipate them. Or at least pretendÂ to.
  • Hubris - The quality that makes you write (and maintain) programs that other people wonâ€™t want to say bad thingsÂ about.
  • Also, I read a quote somewhere saying the mark of a great program is having people use it in ways you didnâ€™t expect, or something likeÂ that.

entry.title: SSH-Notes
entry.content:
Table of Contents
  • Background
  • Authentication
    • Passwords andÂ Keys
    • Handshake

Background

  1. Secure Shell lets you securely connect to remote servers. You connect using an account that exists on the remote server. Once youâ€™ve connected youâ€™ll be dropped into a shellÂ session.

  2. The computer you connect from is the â€œlocalâ€ or â€œclientâ€ computer. The computer you connect to is the â€œhostâ€ or theÂ â€œserverâ€.

  3. When youâ€™re connected to the server using SSH, any commands you input from the client are sent securely and privately (through a â€œtunnelâ€) to the remote computer, where the commands areÂ executed.

  4. SSH is implemented using the client-server model. The server must be running a small app to listen for SSH connections. This kind of app is called a daemon (pronounced day-mon). For SSH to work, the host must be running the SSH daemon. The SSH daemon listens for connections on a specific port (22), authenticates connections requests, and (if the connection request is approved) it will spawn the correct environment. The correct environment is a terminalÂ session.

  5. The client (the computer you connect from) must be running an SSH client, which is a small app that can communicate using the SSH protocol. (A protocol is a set of rules.) It needs to be able to receive information about which host to connect to, which user to connect as and which credentials to use when trying toÂ connect.

Authentication

Passwords andÂ Keys

  1. Clients authenticate using passwords or keys. Passwords are less secure than keys. Keys are very secure. You can also connect using no authentication by specifying a particular IP address IÂ think.

  2. Passwords are encrypted, and are conceptually familiar, but can (and will) be brute forced. There are tools that will block repeated attempts or block/allow authentication attempts from particular IPÂ addresses.

  3. SSH keys using public and private (or secret) key pairs and are very secure. Keys are generated in pairs. The public key can be shared freely without concern. The secret key must be kept as secure and secret as aÂ password.

  4. To authenticate using a key pair, the client must have both keys (a key pair) on their computer. The server must have the public key in a file called authorized_keys. If the server has the private key then something has gone wrong and you should beÂ alarmed.

The server stores the public keys of users who can connect as a particular user in the file ~/.ssh/authorized_keys. The file contains a list of public keys, one public key on eachÂ row.

  1. The default location to store the public key on the remote server is in the users home folder in a subdirectory called .ssh/authorized_keys. The full path would be ~/.ssh/authorized_keys

Handshake

  1. When a client wants to connect to a server using SSH, it tells the server which public key to use. The server then checks in the authorized_keys file for the publicÂ key.

  2. A unique session ID is generated and shared between the client andÂ server.

  3. If the server has the same public key that the client sent when it began the connection attempt, the server generates a random string and encrypts it using the public key. This random string can only be decrypted using the private (secret) key associated with the publicÂ key.

  4. The server sends the encrypted string to the client. The client decrypts it using the secret key and combines the original random string with the session ID. The client then hashes the combined string and sends the hash back to theÂ server.

  5. The server already has the hash of the string combining the original random string and the session ID. If the hash from the client matches the hash on the server, the server can be sure that the client has the privateÂ key.

Source

entry.title: ChezMoi
entry.content:
Table of Contents
  • Background
  • Razor
  • OneÂ Question
  • CommandÂ Reference
  • Links

Background

Chezmoi seems to be dotfiles management for power users. Until a few days ago, when I realised Iâ€™d massively broken a lot of things, Iâ€™d been putting my dotfiles in a version controlled directory and using a shell script to generate symlinks in my homeÂ directory.

This had worked really well for several years. Itâ€™s a great system for maintaining dotfiles on a single machine. But itâ€™s not robust or flexible enough for managing multiple machines or multiple operatingÂ systems.

Also, itâ€™s not just files that sit in $home anymore, I need to track configuration files that live in other places too1.

I needed something more robust and flexible than generating symlinks from a bashÂ script.

Razor

I think I read somewhere that when purchasing a new appliance you should buy the cheapest you think you can get away with, and if that doesnâ€™t work then get the best you can afford. Moving from a custom bash script to Chezmoi is an example of this. My custom bash script was the most basic approach, and it broke badly. Chezmoi seems like the most heavy duty tool for dotfiles management I couldÂ find.

For example, I think Iâ€™m able to encrypt my files using 1Password or similar. I can use Jinja templates to create scripts for different scenarios. I donâ€™t even know what that means at the moment. Iâ€™ve only scratched the surface but Iâ€™m happily managing dotfiles across different machines and updating/modifying them safely. Chezmoi (aliased to cm) is free and OSS so Iâ€™m confident itâ€™ll be â€œmyâ€ tool for the next few decades. Iâ€™m happy to invest a couple of hours to learn a few new habits and iron out a few wrinkles2.

OneÂ Question

I donâ€™t understand why chezmoi cd creates a new shell in order to jump into the Chezmoi directory. Why not simply cd into the Chezmoi directory? Whatâ€™s the advantage/necessity of a newÂ shell?

You have to remember to exit after youâ€™ve done whatever you went there to do, but my habit is to cd or z ... I guess itâ€™s nice to exit and then immediately go back to where ever you were before, but there are other ways of doing that - you could write the current directory to an environment variable. It seems unnecessarilyÂ complex.

CommandÂ Reference

  1. Type cm instead of chezmoi: alias cm="chezmoi"
  2. Show which files have changed: cm status
  3. Start tracking a file: cm add
  4. Update a file, add the file again: cm add ..
  5. Edit tracked version of file: cm edit - donâ€™t think Iâ€™m going to use this, Iâ€™d rather edit the source file, test it, and then update using cm add ..
  6. Differences between local version and tracked versions: cm diff - this tells me which files I need to cm add again. This feels clunky and I suspect there is a better workflow. Parsing git style diff files isÂ horrible.
  7. Clobber local version with the tracked version: cm apply
  8. Dry run and see diff between local version and tracked version: cm -nv apply
  9. Pull the latest changes from your repo and apply them: cm update
  10. Remove a file:
    • Create .chezmoiremove in the sourceÂ directory
    • chezmoi apply --remove --dry-run --verbose
  11. List of managed files: cm managed
  12. List of unmanaged files: cm unmanaged

Links

  • Github
  • ProjectÂ Site
  1. For example, every file in $HOME/.vim/ftplugin/ should be versionÂ controlled. â†©
  2. Happily, it seems like the amount of time required to learn or become familiar with a new tool is decreasing. I guess this is to be expected as experience increases but nonetheless itâ€™s gratifying to realise.
    Dotfiles management was a fairly new and interesting concept when I first began symlinking into my home directory. It still feels amazing to bootstrap a fresh machine and have it feel like home in just a few minutes, but the technicalities of it are nowÂ familiar. â†©

entry.title: I Leaked Credentials Onto A Public GitHubÂ Repo
entry.content:
Table of Contents
  • Donâ€™t post secrets to public GitHubÂ repositories.
  • Background
  • TheÂ hack
  • Remediation
  • Questions
  • Study

Donâ€™t post secrets to public GitHubÂ repositories.

I made this mistake a while ago, and in the interests of openness and learning from others, Iâ€™d like to describe what happened. Maybe itâ€™ll help others avoid the mistake, and maybe Iâ€™ll learn something from any conversation this articleÂ generates.

Background

Using Google Cloud Platform (GCP), Iâ€™ve been doing some work across multiple compute instances. Thankfully, the work wasnâ€™t business critical or on production systems. My account was isolated away from the rest of theÂ business.

As the number of servers I was working with increased, I realised I needed to begin using some tools to automate server setup. This lead me to begin using Ansible, and once Iâ€™d cobbled together a working playbook I pushed my Ansible project to my GitHub accountâ€¦ And accidentally leaked the key for an account Iâ€™d beenÂ using.

TheÂ hack

Within a couple of minutes of pushing the repository to GitHubÂ I:

  • Made the repositoryÂ private.
  • Stopped tracking the keys in git and removed them from the cache git rm -r --cached .
  • Received an email from Google saying theyâ€™d found leakedÂ credentials.

OK, close call. The secret was leaked for less than 5 minutes. On my obscure personalÂ GitHub.

I thought there was nothing to worry about.. But then I noticed some activity in theÂ console.

Compute instances were being created, I could see the list growing rapidly. Over the next few minutes 195 compute instances and disks were being created, each with a unique name in zones across the world. The format of the name was node--. Where type was either application, backup, jenkins, gke, prod, staging, worker, www, build, redis, or runner. Maybe some others too. The number seemed to be 5 randomÂ digits.

Some of the instances were ephemeral. They all had delete protection enabled. I checked the details of a few of them and noticed some scripts that included references toÂ Monero.

So I guess a Monero mining bot was being setÂ up.

The logs showed that GKE and networking resources had also been requested, but the account which the stolen credentials belonged to didnâ€™t have the necessary permissions. Our project also maxed out its quota of compute instances in multiple regions andÂ zones.

Remediation

I deleted the account that had been leaked, and began quantifying the damage. I wanted to know exactly what permissions the key had, which resources could be created, and could the leaked account be used to create other accounts? No, itÂ canâ€™t.

After looking around and becoming confident that it was only 195 compute instances with disks and delete protection that had been created, in regions and zones across the globe, I began to remove them. No other resources had beenÂ provisioned.

It took me 10 minutes and some googling to create the followingÂ workflow:

  1. Get all the compute instances and dump them into a file. I expected to run a script that iterated through the file line by line, setting variables based on the content of the current line: gcloud compute instances list --format 'csv[no-heading](name, zone)' > names.txt

  2. In Vim, find the rows that contain the instances that I donâ€™t want to delete, and remove these from the file. There are a handful of compute instances I want to keep, and 195 that I want to remove. :v/node- shows any rows that donâ€™t includeÂ â€œnode-â€

  3. Loop through the file and for each row, which contains the instance name and itsÂ zone,

    • Remove deleteÂ protection
    • Delete theÂ instance
while IFS=, read -r name zone
  do gcloud compute instances update $name --zone $zone --no-deletion-protection \
  && gcloud compute instances delete $name --zone $zone --quiet
done < names.txt

The --quiet flag is necessary because otherwise gcloud will ask me to confirm that I want to delete the instanceÂ otherwise.

Questions

Iâ€™m surprised by the speed with which the attacker found the leaked credentials. The repo did not belong to the clients account but my own, and I assume that my account is obscure enough to not be on any interesting lists. If my account is being scanned every few minutes, presumably all accounts are being scannedÂ regularly.

How many resources are required to do that? I guess if one of these attacks works you can use the stolen compute to scan more repositories for more leaked credentials. Itâ€™s easy to imagine scenarios where large corporations that are already running complicated cloud infrastructure deployments wouldnâ€™t notice a few (200?) unauthorized compute instancesÂ running.

Study

  • Service accounts on Google CloudÂ Platform.
  • AnsibleÂ videos.
  • SSH crashÂ course.
  • Vagrant crashÂ course.
  • IFS= syntaxÂ explanation.

entry.title: Ansible
entry.content:
Background

Iâ€™ve been spending a lot of time lately working on nodes for various blockchain projects (Polkadot, Cardano, Tron, Binance Chain, Ethereum, â€¦). The rosetta api spec is super interesting, but like most things in crypto the documentation is sometimes wrong or incomplete and there are bugs and undocumentedÂ features.

Each of the nodes runs on a separate server, and we typically have one node for mainnet and another for testnet. Iâ€™m working across mutiple servers, doing difficult stuff, and I want it to be as easy asÂ possible.

I need to reduce friction and cognitiveÂ load.

Accessing the servers is easy - I use Tmux with the continuum and resurrect plugins and maintain different sessions for each type of server. This makes accessing multiple servers during the same work day really simple and effortless. But working on the servers is stillÂ awkward.

On my dev machine I have zsh with syntax highlighting, command completion, and various tools, like z to make navigation supper easy. I also have a lot of aliases defined. E.g. .. â†’ cd ... Working on a remote server should be as convenient and familiar as working on my local machine, so I want to find a way to configure a server the same way as my laptop, and I want to do it automatically so that it can be done many times, with no additionalÂ effort.

Ansible

Ansible seems to be popularÂ because:

  1. Itâ€™sÂ free
  2. Itâ€™s got all the features and capabilities youâ€™re going toÂ need
  3. Itâ€™s agentless - you donâ€™t need to install anything on the machine you want to control - you can use Ansible with anything that you can sshÂ into.

I used the following resources to getÂ started:

  • This useful video gave me some orientation and helped me figure out what I was aiming for and how to get started. Before watching it, I didnâ€™t know â€œwhich way wasÂ upâ€.

  • This blog post showed me how to create an inventory using the gcp_compute plugin.

  • I spent a lot of time being unnecessarily confused about service accounts. I guess until you have 1 success at understanding something you donâ€™t know if youâ€™ve misunderstood by a little or aÂ lot.

  • Once you have an inventory of servers that you want to connect to, you still need to specify (and prepare for) how you will connect to them. Iâ€™d hoped that the gcp_compute plugin would do some heavy lifting for me in this step, but it seems not. It can do lots of useful stuff like creating instances and specifying disk space and networks, but it wonâ€™t really help you ssh into an instance. No matterÂ thoughâ€¦

  • This blog post turned out to be just what I needed. I found it at the beginning of my search when I was trying to create an inventory, and discarded it as almost useful. Turns out that OS Login is the best way to ssh into a GCE instance and once youâ€™ve got your inventory taken care of, this blog post reallyÂ helps.

When I was installing python modules, I had some errors about pyenv shims being incorrect. The scripts were looking for versions that werenâ€™t present. Running pyenv reshash fixed it. Kind of magically, butÂ annoying.

Setting up a service account and giving it the correct permissions took more time and was more confusing than anything to do withÂ Ansible.

I found this blog post about setting up vim for yml files.

The preferred way to install ansible on Mac is using pip.

When you use OS Login the username you have when you ssh into the compute instance will change. This SO question explainsÂ why.

Commands

  • gcloud auth list
  • ansible-config view|list|dump
  • ansible-inventory -i inventory.compute.gcp.yml --graph
  • ansible -i inventory.compute.gcp.yml all -m ping

entry.title: Over-Engineering thisÂ blog
entry.content:
Over the last few weeks Iâ€™ve spent an unreasonable amount of time and energy making unnecessary improvements to thisÂ blog.

Some of these improvementsÂ are:

  1. Adding keyboard shortcuts (type ? to find outÂ which).
  2. Implementing, then reimplementing, and then optimizing client side fuzzyÂ search.
  3. Using src-set to serve responsive images (Image-Process).
  4. Lazy loading images to make this site loadÂ faster.
  5. Compressing page files using brotli and also gzip (Precompress).
  6. Trying (and ultimately failing) to avoid a â€œwhite flashâ€ when dark mode is chosen and a new page loads (Github discussion).

Iâ€™m not really sure why I did it. It makes almost no difference to anyone but me. It felt a bitÂ compulsive.

I like tinkering, and itâ€™s nice to build something that will continue to work with no maintenance. I tell myself that over the next few years I will gain the benefits of these features even when Iâ€™ve forgotten I implementedÂ them.

Itâ€™s taught me a lot of JavaScript, which is a great language to be familiar with - itâ€™s everywhere. I would warmly encourage someone younger than myself to pursue interests for the sake of curiosity and fun. And there is a very high chance that even if no-one uses the shortcuts except me, my new javascript skills will come in useful somewhereÂ else.

But even if they do Iâ€™m not sure its a good enough reason - things should be built when they solve a present problem, not over-engineered for what-ifs and maybes. YAGNI. I wouldnâ€™t let myself do this in a professional capacity. There is a tension between being curious and beingÂ focussed.

Iâ€™m not really sure that I need to justify myself. Its a hobby, I wanted to do it, I enjoy tinkering with web technologies and learning newÂ things.

But also, I lost sleep over this - I stayed up too late, and let it put pressure on otherÂ things.

I know that being curious, and making room to play with interesting things, has been one of the most useful approaches to personal development and up-skilling myself. But there must be aÂ limit..

There is a tension between wasting my time and taking a risk, and it will take a few years before I know for sure if these efforts were worthwhile, orÂ not.

If itâ€™s not fun, donâ€™t doÂ it.

Successful business owners seem to be very good at leaving things alone once theyâ€™re â€œgood enoughâ€, and not being perfectionists. In fact, I think that being a perfectionist is antithetical to being an entrepreneur. I am not a perfectionist, Iâ€™m just really curious and have a big appetite forÂ learning.

But this â€œappetite for learningâ€ stops me from focussing. I let myself become distracted by adding new features to this blog, when instead I should zoom out a bit and think about working towards a more substantial and meaningful goal, to the exclusion of more minorÂ goals.

I think that good entrepreneurs are very focussed, to a fault. I am not that focussed. I am too distracted byÂ life.

Itâ€™s a balancing act, there is a tension between being emotionally and physically present with my family and friends, and ignoring as many things as possible so that I can focus on doing something meaningful that is necessarilyÂ hard.

entry.title: FuseÂ Search
entry.content:
Adding search made the site feel faster and moreÂ accessible

Iâ€™ve reimplemented search on this site using fuse.js instead of tinySearch. You can read about how I implemented tinysearch here.

When I first implemented search I was surprised how much faster and more accessible the site began to feel. I could quickly access any content by typing a few words, I didnâ€™t need to scroll or follow a link.1

This means I can find content without having to think about how to get there - I donâ€™t need to break my flow or concentration. It might sound like a trivially small consideration, but lowering friction or cognitive load in small ways can make the difference between using or not using something when youâ€™re already working hard or concentrating on somethingÂ else.

For example, if I want to look up my notes about using the nohup command, I can quickly go to the site, type / (the keyboard shortcut for search), type â€œnohupâ€ and hit enter. This is all muscle-memory level impulses. I donâ€™t need to think about the content, think about its category or when I posted it, then scroll down and scan a list, or use a mouse to click on intermediate links. Win. Working at the speed of thought rather than the speed of input is a bigÂ deal.

Why I switched from tinySearch toÂ Fuse.js

Before implementing fuse.js, this site had a search feature powered by TinySearch. I wouldnâ€™t have had enough knowledge to implement fuse.js if I hadnâ€™t already learnt some JavaScript whilst setting-upÂ tinySearch.

TinySearch had an example for Pelican Blogs, and a simple and clear readme. By using tinySearch first I saw an example of how to build the JSON array that becomes the search index, and how to implement the javascript thatâ€™s required for client sideÂ search.

Also, in the course of developing and over-engineering this blog Iâ€™ve become much more proficient and comfortable with JavaScript (and jQuery) inÂ general.

Fuse.js is really quite simple to set up once youâ€™re familiar with JavaScript. Itâ€™s much more flexible than tinySearch; you can choose search weights for different fields, accuracy thresholds, and some parameters for the fuzzy searchÂ algorithm.

The general approach is to instantiate an instance of Fuse by calling Fuse with a JSON array for it to parse, along with some options. You then give the instance a string and get back an array of results which you can do whatever you wantÂ with.

The accuracy of the search results is higher with fuse.js and the speed is still acceptable. I did have to do some optimization of the search index that Fuse generates,Â though.

Optimizing the searchÂ index

The â€œnormalâ€ search index that Fuse uses to return results is a JSON array of all the content of all the articles that you want to be able to search. You can generate it using a jinja template or any other way you want. (There simply needs to be a JSON array that the browser downloads and does a fuzzy search on). This gave me a file that was about 4MB. Once I asked Fuse to search the complete text of each article (not just the default first 600 chars, iirc) then speed reallyÂ suffered.

I optimized the index file in the following threeÂ ways:

  1. Removed any non-words. Some of my articles are jupyter notebooks that have been converted to articles (the plugin to do this is one of the reasons why I began using Pelican). When the index is built, lots of code and html gets included, which isnâ€™t helpful. Any â€œwordsâ€ that are more than 20 chars I justÂ delete.

  2. Removed the 150 most common words. Any word that is in many articles is not useful for distinguishing between different articles, so they can be deleted from the index. They donâ€™t add any meaning. I wrote a short pipeline of shell commands using tr, sort, uiq to generate a file with a list of the most common words. I then wrote a python script to update the original search index by removing all the commonÂ words.

  3. Shortened any long words by only keeping the first 12 characters. If a word was 15 characters long, I simply removed that last 3 chars. I figured this would work fine because matching the first 12 characters would already be quite unique and give a goodÂ result.

Doing these 3 optimizations reduced the file size by about 90%. Compressing the JSON using gzip or brotli makes the files even smaller, and now the amount of data transferred to the client seems reasonably small. (This is a static site, and therefore search has to happen clientÂ side.)

The browser would still begin to lag as the search string length increased. It takes more time to search for a 10 character string than for a 5 character string, and initially fuse was doing a search every time a character wasÂ typed.

I wanted the site to feel as fast as possible and thought that if search was paused whilst typing and occurred a short time after the last key was pressed this would be an improvement. I added a short delay of 200ms to the function call, and typing during the delay time resets the time. This reduced the lag and made the search tool feel responsive. I learnt that this is calledÂ â€œdebouncingâ€.

There was some further complexity when I wanted to debounce characters used for searching, but not the navigation or keyboard shortcuts. Getting the debounce function to only run on some key presses was surprisingly complex. It taught me a lot of JavaScript though, and itâ€™s satisfying to have made a useful userÂ interface.

  1. It also immediately gave me the idea to add keyboard shortcuts. Type ? to see whatÂ happened â†©

entry.title: PythonÂ Notes
entry.content:
__call__()

In Python, every time you call a function or method such as my_function() or my_class.my_method() the interpreter will replace the ( with .__call__(

>>> def my_function(x):
>>>    return x+1

>>> my_function.__call__(2)
3

class Prefixer:
    def __init__(self, prefix):
       self.prefix = prefix
    def __call__(self, message):
       return self.prefix + message

Then use prefixer likeÂ this:

>>> simonsays = Prefixer("Simon says: ")
>>> simonsays("jump up high!")
'Simon says: jump up high!'

Every time you call a function or method, youâ€™re really just calling a built in __call__ method.

There should be one, and preferably only one, obvious way to doÂ something

Itâ€™s in the â€˜zen of Pythonâ€™, which is a set of guidelines that help make design decisions. Itâ€™s a choice that Python made, and other languages do itÂ differently.

There are different levels to languages and this applies more to the idiom level than the design pattern level. It applies even less at the architectural level where there can be several equally good ways of organizing business logic and dataÂ representations.

Perl has the â€œTMTOWTDIâ€ (tim towtdi) principle - â€œThereâ€™s More Than One Way To Do Itâ€. Perlâ€™s philosophy is to give users more than one way to doÂ something.

entry.title: AddingÂ Search
entry.content:
Iâ€™ve added search to this blog. Results are generated as you type. Try it by typing / or cmd-k.

If you look on the Pelican plugins index youâ€™ll see that Tipue search is the only search tool with a ready-made Pelican plugin, but unfortunately the project seems to have died and the projects website is now somethingÂ else.

But searching a static site must be quite a common need and googling for alternatives gave me a few choices. Lunr.js seems to be the most popular, but it also seemed fairly complicated and like it was probably more than I needed. I went with Tiny Search because it seemed to do what I needed and was easy to setup. Thereâ€™s even an example for PelicanÂ blogs.

One hurdle to success was minimising the false positives. The default settings seem to prioritise keeping the size of the index small (tiny) over giving a good user experience. Maybe its because the amount of text on my site is significanly less, or more, than the typical use case. Either way, after checking the projectâ€™s issues on Github I found an issue that matched my problem perfectly. The solution is to increase the tiny_magic variable at buildÂ time.

According to the Readme, this requires using a container and building the index using docker run.... Unfortunately the Dockerfile wouldnâ€™t complete without errors. Checking the issues again and adding to the discussion resulted in an alternative Dockerfile being suggested, which works. Woohoo! I could then build the search index with a massive tiny_magic valueÂ (2048).

Then something weird happened. I write in Vim and I use fzf to find and open files. I realised that fzf had stopped working. After some investigating, I realised it was only not working in the blog project, and that fzf.vim calls the fzf CLI tool, which in turn calls the ripgrep tool. The underlying issue was that ripgrep wasnâ€™t working, and after a few hours (sob) of debugging, I found out that one of the things that makes rg special is that it ignores stuff in your .gitignore file. Sneakily, and without me noticing, the Docker image for constructing the tinysearch files had created a .gitignore file with a single entry. The entry was *, which selects everything. So rg was ignoring everything, and giving no results. Which meant I couldnâ€™t find and openÂ files.

I still donâ€™t know how (or which part of) the Dockerfile does this, so Iâ€™ve created a .gitignore-master file which contains the correct content, and after I generate a new search index I replace the new traitorous .gitignore with the contents of .gitignore-master. Iâ€™ll come back to it later when/if I have a better understanding of Dockerfile syntax, orÂ Rust.

Adding search to the site made the content feel a lot closer and more accessible. Once it was working I immediately wanted to use some keyboard shortcuts to open the search box and select results. Kind of like tailwindcss.com does it. It feels really fast andÂ precise.

Googling for some jquery packages, and also some vanilla javaScript showed me enough to get things working. You can hit / or ctrl-k or cmd-k and bring up a search box that populates results as youÂ type!

Only whole words are matched unfortunately, but its still a super useful feature. The search index includes article content as well as article titles and categories. Iâ€™d like to tweak a few of the keyboard shortcut behaviours, and add the contents of various pages (which arenâ€™t articles) to the searchÂ index.

entry.title: Cardano: GeneratingÂ Addresses
entry.content:
If many different customers are to deposit or send ADA (The unit of currency on the Cardano blockchain) to a Cardano node, it will be necessary to determine which customer is responsible for each transaction so that the correct customer account can beÂ updated.

As with many things involving blockchains, this initially seemed like a simple requirement but involved several hours ofÂ work.

Cardano wallets are generated using a parameter called ADDRESS_POOL_GAP. The default value is 20, and is the number of unused addresses that the node will generate and return to a client using the REST API. If one of the addresses is used, the node will automatically generate another so that there are always 20 unusedÂ addresses.

This is probably very convenient for personal use. If I want someone to send me some funds, I can make a simple api call using cURL and get a fresh address. But if you are running a service, weather its e-commerce or a financial service, its not really good enough. Some advice on the forums says to generate a wallet with a very large ADDRESS_POOL_GAP value such as 10,000 and just generate a new wallet when you run out of fresh addresses, but it still feels like aÂ compromise.

But lets explain our situation in more detail first. If a customer wants to send us some ADA, we want to give them a fresh address thatâ€™s never been used before and that only they have. Then we know that any funds that arrive to that address are from a particular customer. However we donâ€™t know if the customer will actually use the address and transfer any funds. The address might remain unused or it might not. Nevertheless, that address is now reserved for them, and no one else can useÂ it.

In this way, we might need to generate and maintain a list of thousands of addresses that are never used. Using ADDRESS_POOL_GAP for this seems like a badÂ solution.

Fortunately, Cardano-Addresses has the answer, albeit in a fairly convoluted and obscured form. If you have the mnemonic that was used to generate a wallet originally, you can generate 2^31 unique addresses likeÂ so:

Clone the repo and build the dockerÂ image:

git clone https://github.com/input-output-hk/cardano-wallet 
docker build -t cardano-address .

Get the mnemonic and generate a file containing a list of space separated words on oneÂ row.

Run theÂ following:

export increment=0
((increment=increment+1)) && cat mnumonic.txt | docker run --rm -i cardano-address key from-recovery-phrase Shelley | docker run --rm -i cardano-address key child 1852H/1815H/0H/0/$increment | docker run --rm -i cardano-address key public --with-chain-code  | docker run --rm -i cardano-address address payment --network-tag testnet > payment.addr && cat payment.addr ;echo

entry.title: Binance-Chain: Running aÂ node
entry.content:
This week Iâ€™ve been setting up a binance-chain node. Unlike Polkadot or Cardano, Iâ€™m not going to run it from a container until itâ€™s workingÂ reliably.

Installation

Fast-sync isnâ€™t the fastest way to sync your node, hot-sync is. Using install.sh should put the correct default values in the $BNCHOME/config/config.toml file, but I needed to adjust ping_interval and pong_timeout to the recommendedÂ values.

entry.title: nohup and BackgroundÂ Processes
entry.content:
Stop stuff fromÂ stopping

If you run a command in a terminal session and the terminal session is disconnected, the processes running in it will also beÂ terminated.

I discovered this when I was trying to download a ~500gb database overnight. I logged in the next morning expecting to see a completed download, but found I only had half theÂ file.

Use nohup to ignore HUP signals

One solution to this seems to be to use nohup, a command that ignores the HUP signal. It stops your programme from stopping if the terminal session its running in isÂ stopped.

By convention, the HUP signal is the method used by a terminal to warn dependent processes that it is about toÂ logout.

You probably want to run nohup in the background. You might want to prevent it from creating nohup.out.

Close or redirect fd0 -Â fd2

On Linux, nohup automatically closes stdin. If youâ€™re using MacOS or BSD this doesnâ€™t automatically happen, so you might want to redirect it yourself. This is because if a background process tries to read anything from stdin then it will pause itself whilst it waits for you to bring it to the foreground and type some input. This is probably a waste ofÂ time.

If nohup detects that you have redirected stdout and stderr then it wonâ€™t create nohup.out.

As with all commands, if you put & at the end of the command, it will run in the background. You can bring it to the foreground by running fg, or see a list of jobs by running jobs.

If you redirect input to /dev/null () you will stop the program from receiving keyboard (stdin) input, but you wonâ€™t prevent it from accessing the terminal directly. Also you havenâ€™t removed the program from the shellâ€™s processÂ group.

Stopping signals using disown

If you want to remove a program from the shellâ€™s process group, then immediately after youâ€™ve run the command to start your programme, run disown with no arguments. This will make the background process no longer associated with the shell job and it wont have any signals forwarded to it by theÂ shell.

A disowned process gets nothing (no signals) sent to it by the shell. But without a nohup it will still be sent a HUP signal sent via other means, such as a manual kill command.

A nohuped process will ignore any and all HUP signal, no matter how they areÂ sent.

Source

UpdateÂ (2021-03-31):

Use w to see who is logged in and what they are doing. Itâ€™s summary of every user logged into a computer, what each user is currently doing, and the load all the currentÂ activity.

Itâ€™s a combination of who, uptime, and ps -a.

ProcessÂ Groups

A collection of one or more processes. Itâ€™s used to control the distribution of a signal. When a signal is directed to a process group, the signal is delivered to each process that is a member of theÂ group.

Sessions

A collection of one or more process groups. A process may not create a process group that belongs to another session. A process is not permitted to join a process group that is a member of another session. A process is not permitted to migrate from one session toÂ another.

entry.title: File Descriptors andÂ /dev/null
entry.content:
/dev/null

In Linux everything is a file, including virtual devices like keyboards. Processes (programmes) can request access to or from theseÂ devices.

The only difference between these virtual device â€œfilesâ€ and real files, is that for a virtual device the OS generates the data that goes into the file, instead of reading the data fromÂ storage.

/dev/null is a virtual device that looks like a file and is used to write output into a black hole that is discarded, lost forever and never seen. It isnâ€™t written to theÂ terminal.

FileÂ Descriptors

File descriptors are integer values assigned to aÂ file.

  • stdin has a file descriptor ofÂ 0
  • stdout has a file descriptor ofÂ 1
  • stderr has a file descriptor ofÂ 2

Two outputs are generated whenever a CLI is run stdout and stderr. By default, both these data streams are associated with the terminal. You can use file descriptors to redirectÂ them.

If a command exits successfully, the exit status isÂ 0.

If it exits unsuccessfully, the exit status will be somethingÂ else.

If you donâ€™t specify which file descriptor you want to use, bash will use stdout byÂ default.

The following redirects stdout away from the terminal and into /dev/null.

$ echo â€œHello Worldâ€ > log.txt

This will redirect stderr into aÂ file:

$ asdfadsa 2> error.txt

If you run a command that generates lots of error messages along with â€œgoodâ€ messages, you can redirect all the error messages (stderr) into /dev/null so that you can only see the useful stdout messages.Â e.g.:

$ grep -r hello /sys/ 2> /dev/null
